instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
Board is taking 0.160 mA

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  : 0.60 mA

=====================================

How would I know if its <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> or <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

I want to know how to approach this issue ? I don't want to use hit and trail method

I appreciate all your help  Sir

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  : 0.60 mA"
This is nonsense; make difference between current and voltage!

Look at power on sequence and tell us which voltages do you get on the board.
To hunt <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, you must get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> first; it is pulled-up there.

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
My bad , it was Voltage not Ampere
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> : 0.60 V

=================================
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> Present

<RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> 
Pin 1 = 3.3V
Pin 2= 0.6 V

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
In such case, you should have voltage on some big coils.
Something pulls down <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal.
If one big coil has no voltage, its power good signal can be the reason.

Try first removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>...

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>     Pin 1 = 0.60V  Pin 2 =0.60V
<RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>     Pin 1 = 0.60V  Pin 2 =0.60V
<RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>     Pin 1= 0.60V  Pin 2 = 0.60V
<RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR>     Pin 1= 0.28V  Pin 2 = 0.60V


L7130 =8.6V
L7520 = 5.0V
L7560 = 3.3V
L7430 = 1.08V
L7630 = 1.05V
L7310 =0V
L7320 = 0V

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
Remove the resistors from <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> (one by one); check when the signal comes high.
Keep <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> in place!

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
Removed
 <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> & <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR> Pin 1 = 3.3 V Pin 2 = 3.3 0V
<RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR> Pin 1 = 3.3 V Pin 2 = 3.3 0V
<RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR> Pin 1 = 3.3 V Pin 2 = 3.3 0V

<RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>  PIN 1 : 3.3 V & Pin 2= 3.3V

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
So you have a problem in <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> area.
Should get 1.2V at <RESISTOR>R7450</RESISTOR>, not 1.08V.
Check the area for corrosion.

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message: I cannot see any corrosion or anything physical near <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. Should I start with disconnecting coil or replacing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>?  and Should I put <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> back to its place now?

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
You can resolder <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.

Didn't check voltage on <RESISTOR>R7450</RESISTOR>?
L7310/20 no voltage yet?

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> Soldered Back , <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> still out of board

========================
<RESISTOR>R7450</RESISTOR> = 0.65 V

L7310/20 = 1.8 V

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7450</RESISTOR> = 0.65 V"
Now dropped from 1.08V?

Check <RESISTOR>R7415</RESISTOR>/16/60 and R/<CAPACITOR>C7425</CAPACITOR>.
If all good, try changing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
When I took off <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> , <RESISTOR>R7450</RESISTOR> dropped from 1.08 to 0.65V

<RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> still out of board 

After Changing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>

<RESISTOR>R7450</RESISTOR> = 0.48V

threads.title: 820 000165   <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  Missing
threads.message:
Did you check above mentioned components?
Post <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 12, 6, 16, 17, 1, 5, 9.
